intro: Brassica blancoana, commonly known as the white mustard, is a herbaceous annual plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like cabbage and broccoli. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring alternate, pinnately lobed leaves and small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its seeds are small and capsule-like, containing a high oil content, which makes them valuable for both culinary and industrial uses. Brassica blancoana is often found in disturbed soils and is considered a weed in agricultural settings.
